Question: Parse Excel data in Java effectivley: :I'm supposed to realize a Java application that should retrieve data out of an excel spreadsheet and link it to some objects I've already created in order to apply some calculations on them, then display the result .About the app==> The excel spreadsheet is a survey to measure a bank's clients satisfaction about the bank's services.==> The application should parse the data in the spreadsheet, and do some calculations on it.==> The result should be displayed using an interactive GUI .What I've done so farI've analysed to problem and create all the objects I will need in my application.I Actually did some search here on stackoverflow.com and think that Apache POI would be very useful.Where I need helpThe problem is that I have no idea about what I should begin with .Any suggestions on how to accomplish this , what tools, languages, API or design pattern I should use is more than welcome.
Please using this api: Iterator.next.

Question: Parse Excel data in Java effectivley: :I'm supposed to realize a Java application that should retrieve data out of an excel spreadsheet and link it to some objects I've already created in order to apply some calculations on them, then display the result .About the app==> The excel spreadsheet is a survey to measure a bank's clients satisfaction about the bank's services.==> The application should parse the data in the spreadsheet, and do some calculations on it.==> The result should be displayed using an interactive GUI .What I've done so farI've analysed to problem and create all the objects I will need in my application.I Actually did some search here on stackoverflow.com and think that Apache POI would be very useful.Where I need helpThe problem is that I have no idea about what I should begin with .Any suggestions on how to accomplish this , what tools, languages, API or design pattern I should use is more than welcome.
Please using this api: Iterator.next.
Answer: <<<api>>>: Apache POI
<<<code>>>: 
```java
import org.apache.poi.ss.usermodel.*;
import org.apache.poi.xssf.usermodel.XSSFWorkbook;

import java.io.File;
import java.io.FileInputStream;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.util.Iterator;

public class ExcelDataParser {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
        FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(new File("path_to_your_file"));
        Workbook workbook = new XSSFWorkbook(fis);
        Sheet sheet = workbook.getSheetAt(0);
        Iterator<Row> rowIterator = sheet.iterator();
        while (rowIterator.hasNext()) {
            Row row = rowIterator.next();
            Iterator<Cell> cellIterator = row.cellIterator();
            while (cellIterator.hasNext()) {
                Cell cell = cellIterator.next();
                // Depending on cell type, get the value
                switch (cell.getCellType()) {
                    case NUMERIC:
                        System.out.print(cell.getNumericCellValue() + " ");
                        break;
                    case STRING:
                        System.out.print(cell.getStringCellValue() + " ");
                        break;
                }
            }
            System.out.println();
        }
        workbook.close();
        fis.close();
    }
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: This code reads an Excel file using Apache POI and prints the data to the console. You can modify it to suit your needs.

Please note that you need to replace "path_to_your_file" with the actual path to your Excel file.

For the GUI part, you can use JavaFX or Swing depending on your preference. You can create a table in the GUI to display the results.

For the calculations, you can create methods to calculate the average, median, etc. based on the data you get from the Excel file.

Remember to handle exceptions properly in your code.

This should give you a good starting point.

Please let me know if you need further assistance.

Note: Apache POI is a powerful library for reading and writing various formats of spreadsheet files, including Excel. It is widely used in Java applications for handling Excel files.
